text: Woua! Very nice! One thing I find interesting with this approach, is that it forces you (as a designer of a programming system) to have high level programming constructs as close as possible to the "end-user" programmer interests. I mean, often in general purpose language, you have some kind of surrounding code (preparing variable, accessing data, etc., sometime boilerplate code) which is not that necessary. As programmers it can be part of our job to make this code less necessary and to produce higher abstractions, but with a system like the one in the video, you are forced to have these very high level constructs (and I understand it is at the core of the design of StoryScript).

text: <@UJ6LDMMN0> exactly! I'm very pleased to hear your feedback. It is exactly as you say it: in the design of Storyscript.

text: Hey folks, I’m looking for people with experience/interest in Structured Editors to try out Dark’s editor and make suggestions (we’re struggling to make it feel really good and would love some help). If you’d be interested, post/DM your email and I’ll get you an invite

text:
I intend to try to make something this week - a combination of the games Kahoot and Psych that I once made in Python (but not published) which should be a good game for birthday video chats.
After that I’ll hopefully have some feedback to share :crossed_fingers:
